Literature Review: The order Mononegavirales, comprising nonsegmented, negative-strand RNA viruses (nsNSVs), includes several significant human pathogens such as rabies virus, Ebola virus, and respiratory syncytial virus. Central to the replication cycle of these viruses is the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), which performs both transcription and replication of the viral genome. Recent structural and functional studies have provided unprecedented insights into the mechanisms underlying these processes, revolutionizing our understanding of nsNSV polymerases.The nsNSV polymerase is a large, multi-domain protein complex that includes the catalytic L protein and the essential cofactor P protein. Structural studies have revealed that the L protein consists of several conserved domains, including the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) domain, the capping domain, and the methyltransferase domain. These domains work in concert to produce capped and polyadenylated mRNAs during transcription and full-length antigenomes and genomes during replication.One of the most significant breakthroughs in understanding nsNSV polymerase structure came from the cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structure of the vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) polymerase, as reported by Liang et al. (2015). This structure revealed the intricate organization of the L protein domains and provided insights into the mechanisms of RNA synthesis and capping. The RdRp domain was found to adopt a right-hand configuration, similar to other viral polymerases, with finger, palm, and thumb subdomains surrounding the active site.Following this landmark study, structures of polymerases from other nsNSVs have been solved, including those from respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and human metapneumovirus (HMPV), as reported by Gilman et al. (2019) and Pan et al. (2019), respectively. These structures have revealed both conserved features and virus-specific adaptations, providing a broader understanding of nsNSV polymerase function across different viral families.A key feature of nsNSV polymerases is their ability to switch between different functional modes for transcription and replication. Structural and biochemical studies have shed light on the conformational changes that facilitate these transitions. For instance, Jenni et al. (2019) described the structure of the RSV polymerase in different functional states, revealing how the polymerase rearranges to accommodate template RNA and initiate RNA synthesis.The initiation of RNA synthesis is a critical step in both transcription and replication. Studies by Noton et al. (2012) and Ogino et al. (2019) have elucidated the mechanisms of de novo initiation and the role of conserved priming residues in the polymerase active site. These findings have important implications for understanding viral replication and developing antiviral strategies targeting the initiation step.Another crucial aspect of nsNSV polymerase function is the capping of viral mRNAs. The capping domain of the L protein performs a unique polyribonucleotidyltransferase (PRNTase) reaction to add the cap structure. Structural studies by Ogino et al. (2010) and Neubauer et al. (2016) have revealed the molecular basis of this reaction and how it is coordinated with RNA synthesis.The processivity and fidelity of RNA synthesis are also critical for viral replication. Recent work by Duprex et al. (2018) has shown that mutations in the L protein can affect both processivity and fidelity, with implications for viral evolution and pathogenesis. Understanding these mechanisms at a molecular level could lead to new strategies for attenuating viruses for vaccine development.The interaction between the L protein and its cofactor, the P protein, is essential for polymerase function. Structural studies by Abdella et al. (2020) have revealed how the P protein interacts with the L protein and modulates its activity. These findings provide insights into the regulation of polymerase function and offer potential targets for antiviral intervention.Despite these significant advances, many questions remain regarding nsNSV polymerase function. For example, the mechanisms of transcription termination and reinitiation, as well as the switch between transcription and replication modes, are not fully understood. Additionally, the role of host factors in modulating polymerase activity and the potential for targeting polymerase-host interactions for antiviral therapy remain active areas of research.In conclusion, recent structural and functional studies have greatly advanced our understanding of nsNSV polymerase mechanisms. These insights have not only shed light on fundamental aspects of viral replication but also opened new avenues for the development of antiviral strategies and improved vaccine design. As research in this field continues to progress, we can expect further revelations about the intricate workings of these fascinating molecular machines.
